entry.title: Official The Witcher 3 modding tool is available for playtesting
entry.summary:
Fans have been modding The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt on PC ever since it launched back in 2015. Later this year, though, developer CD Projekt Red is releasing its own modding tool for the game, but you can test it out for yourself before then.
Signing up for playtest access is incredibly simple; just click the option for it on the tool's Steam listing. You aren't guaranteed to gain access straightaway, though, as CD Projekt Red has noted in a Steam news post that playtest access will be distributed in batches. So, be sure to keep an eye on your Steam Library for when The Witcher 3 REDkit Playtest is added. Prospective playtesters have also been warned that since they'll be trying out a beta version of the tool, it's bound to have issues that haven't been ironed out yet.
Image via CD Projekt Red
The tool promises to be incredibly comprehensive since it's based on the very tools the developers used for making The Witcher 3. CD Projekt Red has said this should "allow for nearly limitless freedom in modding [The Witcher 3] and, best of all, it'll be a free download, so there'll be no reason for modders not to at least try it out. With how creative modders can be, it'll be interesting to see what they can come up with using an officially supported tool like this.
This isn't the first time CD Projekt Red has offered official mod support. Cyberpunk 2077 has its own free REDMod DLC that can be used to create and install mods for the game. Hopefully, such a tool will also be made for the next Witcher game as well, and not release nearly 10 years after the game does. Unofficially dubbed The Witcher 4, the game has over 400 developers working on it according to an earnings call from last month, but there are still no real details on it, not even it's actual title.

entry.title: Helldivers 2 dev explains delay for fixes for known glitches
entry.summary:
Helldivers 2 is one of 2024's most popular games, but like many titles, it's been affected by bugs since its release. With some fans complaining about the lack of fixes, an Arrowhead community manager has explained what's causing the delays.
In a message in the official Helldivers 2 Discord server following April 16's patch 01.000.203, Spitz explained that most of the bugs in the known issues list are "actively being worked on, but they're either large fixes that require a bit of time or low-priority issues behind other things, and most should be patched in the next major build."
He then revealed that one of the major reasons slowing down bug fixes is the warbonds, as the current release schedule of one per month leaves them struggling to find the time to address problems.
Warbonds make fixing issues tough. Screenshot via Destructoid
On hearing this, fans of the game on Reddit immediately suggested that Arrowhead should skip a warbond for a month to focus on fixes. However, in response, Spitz said: "Sadly it's not that simple, skipping a warbond for a month is a huge company decision."
It's not as simple as just skipping things. Screenshot via Destructoid
None of this is helped by the fact that there is no dedicated team who's only job is to fix bugs either. As explained by the community manager: "The people who work on bugs with armor and guns are the same people who make the new guns and armor, so the nature of the bug really determines which team is focused on fixing it."
Unfortunately, there are plenty of bugs that need to be looked into at the moment, with friend invites and cross-play severely affected, damage-over-time effects only working for hosts, and weapons like the Sickle that can't shoot through the foliage.
For Helldivers 2 fans, the hope is that a majority of these glitches will be fixed when the next major update drops.

Planet of Lana gathers together the most appealing elements of all of these â€“ along with other notable examples of the genre â€“ and rolls them up into something modern and engaging, if not entirely original. entry.title: Keanu Reeves Cast as Shadow in Sonic 3
entry.summary:
The Sonic movie franchise has been on a tear over the past four years, earning over $700 million in global box office earnings and adding a couple more titles to the list of successful video game movie adaptations.
They've done so by collecting a cast of stellar actors to play and voice their characters, from Jim Carrey's manic Dr. Robotnik to Idris Elba's indomitable Knuckles. With Sonic 3 on the way and a huge cast of characters still to fill, fans knew there would be more amazing casting announcements in the future.
Still, I don't know if anyone expected Mr. John Wick himself, Keanu Reeves, to join the fun.
Shadow the Hedgehog's film series voice actor has been revealed
As stated by the Hollywood Reporter, Keanu Reeves is set to star in Sonic 3 as Shadow the Hedgehog, Sonic's dark, edgy opposite. Given Keanu's recent success as John Wick, we see how the casting may make sense. Shadow is a motorcycle-riding, gun-wielding (sometimes) antihero, turned towards chaos by the death of his longtime companion, Maria Robotnik. Mourning her loss, he originally turns to evil before finding his way back to the good side, though with a 'through any means necessary' moral compass. John Wick toes the same line, originally seeking revenge before turning to dismantle the High Table. The parallels are numerous, and it seems obvious that Keanu should be a perfect fit for the role.
While we don't have access to a Sonic 3 trailer yet, one was shown privately at Cinemacon in Las Vegas, and rumors seem to point to Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, and maybe even Robotnik, joining forces to stop Shadow's rampage.
Personally, I hadn't been very hyped for this movie. Now? I'm through the roof. I'm so ready to hear Keanu Reeves voice Shadow the Hedgehog as he wreaks havoc and causes mayhem in his quest to attain the Chaos Emeralds, jumping over buildings on a souped-up motorcycle.
And maybe, if my prayers are answered, they'll give him a gun too.

entry.title: XDefiant now slated for summer releaseâ€”if you choose to believe it
entry.summary:
Delays have plagued Ubisoft's Call of Duty rival XDefiant, but there may finally be light at the end of the tunnel. The FPS title is now slated for a summer releaseâ€”should you choose to believe the game will actually ever come out.
XDefiant was first scheduled to release in the summer of 2023 but missed that window due to issues with the in-game party system, and the need to improve the game's netcode. It was then penciled in to drop before the end of March 2024, but the developers stated that "some improvements" were still required and that the deadline wouldn't be met either.
Now, according to XDefiant Alerts on X, formerly Twitter, the game is now looking at "an expected release date of this summer," should an upcoming test session go well.
The test will take place on Friday, April 19, and will last just 12 hours. Should that go well, the test will be extended until Sunday, with the summer release date set to be confirmed following the end of the session.
Truthfully, even with the test set for this weekend, I'm finding it hard to have any faith that we'll see the game this summer. It's hard to believe it's been almost a year since the last Open Session playtest back in June 2023, and we're still waiting for an official release date.
It feels like XDefiant has missed its big chance, with the positive release of Modern Warfare 3 hurting the game badly. It's hard to be excited about a Call of Duty rival if CoD has a good game out.
Between all that, and reports that the development of the game has been hampered by "unnecessary changes" demanded by Ubisoft, it's hard even to believe we'll get our hands on the game this year. For Ubisoft's sake, they'll need to hope this week's playtest goes well.

entry.title: Helldivers 2 patch 01.000.203 has fixed that incorrect armor passive
entry.summary:
Arrowhead Game Studios' latest patch for Helldivers 2 is here and has not only addressed an issue with a certain armor passive, but it has also fixed various crashes.
Last week, alongside the release of the Democratic Detonation Warbond, Arrowhead admitted that one of the new armor typesâ€”the CE-27 Ground Breakerâ€”had the wrong passive attached to it. It was advertised to have the Engineering Kit passive, one of Helldivers 2's better armor passives, but instead arrived with the less impressive Servo-Assisted passive.
It fortunately hasn't taken Arrowhead long to fix this. Patch 01.000.203 has now been issued so, once you download it, your Ground Breaker armor should sport its original Engineering Kit Passive. The patch has also ironed out multiple crashes, including ones that could occur during the loadout screen when players left or joined a game. Plus, the amount of damage dealt to enemies should no longer sometimes be different between the PC and PlayStation 5 versions of the game.
While these fixes are welcomed, Helldivers 2 is unfortunately still plagued by a long list of issues and bugs. You can view the full list of known issues Arrowhead is working on via the Steam update, which includes the Superior Packing Methodology ship module not working properly and delays in Medal and Super Credit payouts.
Judging by the first responses on Reddit, players are certainly appreciative of the fixes, but remain concerned that some bugs that have long been a problem still haven't been taken care of. Several players, like SmugSkeletor and CommunismBots, are disappointed to see the bug causing damage-over-time effects to only apply to a game's host continue to plague Helldivers 2. The known issues list also makes no mention of how overly powerful fire damage is, but the studio did recently promise it would address this too.

entry.title: Kevin Durantâ€™s dream Warzone Operator would have been gameâ€™s best skin ever
entry.summary:
Kevin Durant received his official Call of Duty Operator skin back in May 2023, but if the two-time NBA Champion had gotten his way, we'd have seen the Slim Reaper roaming around Warzone, and it would have been the coolest thing ever.
In an appearance on the Aux Money podcast with Chase B, KD explained that when he gets a day off, he loves to relax at home and play Warzone, and is currently ranking up the BP50 and the HRM-9. During the interview, the 14-time NBA All-Star explained how his Operator skin came to be, before revealing what he really wanted it to look like.
KD got his own Warzone skin, but it's not how he dreamt it. Image via Activision
When asked the origins of his Operator, Durant said it happened "just from playing it," and that he went to play Modern Warfare 3 early too, where he "vibed with them," thus creating the chance for his skin to happen.
"I want to update it too," KD revealed. "I wanted to do the Slim Reaper in there, with the hood on, the long [cloak]. I wanted my weapon to be the scythe, and I wanted to make him 6'9". They were like 'Nah, you'll stand out too much. You'd get killed too easily.'"
I can only imagine how nuts it would have been to see KD, dressed like the Grim Reaper, running around Warzone maps, towering over everyone. He may have been easy to spot, but I have to agree with the Phoenix Suns star, who thought it would have been "fire."
As for who could be the next NBA star to appear in Warzone, Durant spoke glowingly about teammate Devin Booker's skills, calling him "elite." According to KD, Booker averages 12 kills a game, and with links to FaZe Clan and 100 Thieves, it wouldn't be a surprise to see him appear in the CoD Shop.

entry.title: Dredge Live-Action Feature Film Announced
entry.summary: In March 2023, Dredge became one of the most talked-about games of the year thanks to its combination of engaging fishing mechanics, an enthralling atmosphere, and a fun story involving sinister secrets buried at sea. "We are excited to partner with such an experienced studio team to bring the world we created to live action and ignite the imagination of audiences across the globe," a joint statement from the Black Salt Games team said in that same press release. Story Kitchen was founded in 2022 byÂ Sonic the Hedgehog 2Â producer Dmitri M. Johnson, former APA Agent Mike Goldberg, and their production and development executives Timothy I. Stevenson and Dan Jevons. "Dredge is a captivatingly eerie and profoundly rich story that had us completely hooked from the very beginning," a joint statement from Story Kitchen said in the press release. Dredge currently has an 80 out of 100 rating on the reviews aggregate website Metacritic. entry.title: World Of Warcraft wasn't the biggest threat to The Elder Scrolls Online; it was Skyrim
entry.summary: When Bethesda was working out how to turn their popular Elder Scrolls RPGs into an online behemoth to rival World Of Warcraft back in the late 00s, the initial pitch was "Elder Scrolls with friends," creative director Rich Lambert tells me. A simple idea on paper, perhaps, but one that proved to be a lot more complicated in the realisation of it. Zenimax Online Studios was founded in 2007, a year after The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion landed to universal critical praise, but it wasn't until seven years later that The Elder Scrolls Online finally released for PC in 2014. At launch "we were walking this weird line between 'online game' and 'Elder Scrolls game'," Lambert says. "We didn't do either of them particularly well." Ten years later, though, The Elder Scrolls Online is thriving. At last count, the game has over 24 million players galloping about the plains of Tamriel, and later this June, it will receive its eighth major Chapter expansion, Gold Road, which adds Oblivion's West Weald to the game and wraps up the mystery of the new Daedric Prince that arrived at the end of the previous expansion, Necrom. But the path ESO has taken to get here hasn't been nearly as glittering, with its PC launch in particular generating "a lot of feedback", as studio director Matt Firor told press at the game's tenth anniversary event last week. In fact, it wasn't until ESO came to consoles in 2015 that the game really found its voice, says Lambert. "We had to really figure out what we wanted to be, and we chose 'Elder Scrolls'. As soon as we hit that core pillar of 'It's Elder Scrolls first, online second,' then it really just helped inform everything we've done since." Trouble is, when the thrust of ESO's development straddled the launch of two very different Elder Scrolls games, even nailing down that first part of the pillar proved to be more challenging than expected.
